metadata./Keywords: Retrocaval ureter; Congenital anomaly; Inferior vena cava; Ipsilateral hydronephrosis
metadata./Title: Retrocaval ureter: a case report and review of the literature
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background The retrocaval ureter is a rare congenital anomaly resulting from abnormal development of the infe rior vena cava. The obstruction is usually at the retrocaval segment of the ureter, as it lies between the inferior vena 
cava and the body of the third lumbar vertebra. Computed tomography intravenous urography is the gold standard for investigating this condition and can reveal ipsilateral hydronephrosis and the fishhook sign or sickle sign 
of the proximal ureter, depending on the type of retrocaval ureter.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We present the case of a 30-year-old African female who presented with intermittent dull right 
flank pain for 3 years. Computed tomography intravenous urography revealed isolated moderate right hydrone phrosis with a fishhook sign in the proximal ureter. Surgical correction was performed, and the patient was followed 
for 6 months with improved renal function.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Surgery remains the sole definitive management of the retrocaval ureter for symptomatic patients 
and those with worsening hydronephrosis or differential renal function.
Keywords  Retrocaval ureter, Congenital anomaly, Inferior vena cava, Ipsilateral hydronephrosis
sections.Introduction:
Introduction
The retrocaval ureter, also referred to as the pre-ureteral 
vena cava, is a rare congenital entity in which the ure ter passes posterior to the inferior vena cava (IVC) [1]. 
It
sections.Results:
results from abnormal persistence of the right subcar dinal vein ventral to the ureter during IVC embryogen esis [2]. The developing right ureter courses behind and 
medial to the IVC over the pedicle of the L3–L4 vertebrae 
and then exits between the IVC and the aorta, returning to its normal position. This produces varying degrees of 
hydroureteronephrosis [3].
Even though it is a congenital defect, individuals typi cally do not exhibit symptoms until their third or fourth 
decade of life. Symptoms arise due to pelvic-ureteric 
junction obstruction secondary to either kinking of the 
ureter, adynamic retrocaval segment of ureter, or com pression of retrocaval segment of ureter against psoas 
muscle [4]. Also symptoms may arise from complications 
of pelvic ureteric junction obstruction, such as second ary nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis [5]. The clinical 
symptomatology of the retrocaval ureter is not specific to 
the abnormality, and the diagnosis is based on radiologi cal investigations, especially contrasted abdominal pelvic 
computed tomography (CT) scans [6].
We present the case of a 30-year-old female with a type 
I retrocaval ureter who presented with intermittent dull 
right flank pain for 6  years. CT intravenous urography 
(IVU) revealed isolated moderate hydronephrosis with *Correspondence:
Charles John Nhungo
charlesnhungo@gmail.com
1 Department of Urology, Muhimbili National Hospital, Dar es Salaam, 
Tanzania

Tanzania
Page 2 of 5 Maro et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:573 
fishhook sign in the proximal ureter. Surgical correction 
was performed by mobilization of the retrocaval ureter 
and uretero-ureteric anastomosis. The patient was fol lowed for 6 months and experienced improved renal out comes and symptom resolution.
Case presentation
We report a case of 30-year-old African female who 
presented at our urology outpatient clinic with a chief 
complaint of intermittent severe dull right flank pain 
for 3 years; recently, it was associated with general body 
malaise accompanied by episodes of nausea and vomit ing. The patient denied history of fever, hematuria, or 
lower urinary tract symptoms. Two years prior to admis sion she did an abdominopelvic ultrasound at a periph eral hospital and was diagnosed with recurrent chronic 
cystitis and right hydronephrosis. She was treated with 
antibiotics and her physician decided to do endoscopic 
double-J (DJ) stent insertion. Stent was left for 3 months 
and during this time she reported improvement in 
abdominal pain; however, pain recurred after DJ stent 
removal. She reported a subsequent DJ stent insertion, 
which resulted again in symptom alleviation. The patient 
denied history of similar illness in her family.
Physical examination revealed normal findings. 
Abdominal examination revealed mild tenderness in the 
right flank with non-ballotable kidneys. The results of 
laboratory investigations, such as hematology and bio chemistry, were within the normal range.
Kidney–ureter–bladder (KUB) ultrasonography 
revealed proximal hydro-ureteropelvic distension with 
moderate loss of corticomedullary differentiation in the 
right kidney. A routine X-ray of the kidney–ureter–blad der was normal, with no evidence of renal calculi. A 
contrasted abdominopelvic computed tomography vol ume-rendered image exquisitely depicted the “fishhook” 
or “S-shaped appearance” of the right ureter at the level 
of L3 vertebra with moderate hydronephrosis (Fig.  1) and 
dilatation of the ureter proximal to it and normal left kid ney signaling the right retrocaval ureter and pelvi-ure teric junction obstruction (Fig. 2 and 3).
The patient underwent ureteroureterostomy after 
consenting, through a right flank incision via an extra peritoneal approach we found a dilated renal pelvis, 
retrocaval ureter crossing the inferior vena cava at the 
level of lumbar three (L3) vertebra (Fig.  4) and stenotic 
retrocaval segment of ureter. After isolating the right 
renal pelvis and ureter (Fig.  5), the ureter was marked 
with a vessel loop and mobilized cranially and caudally 
to stenotic retrocaval segment. The ureters were han dled carefully and non-traumatically to spare its blood 
supply and for prevention of anastomotic leak or atro phy. Both ends of the ureter adventitia were freed of 
Fig. 1 Computed tomography urography volume-rendered 
image exquisitely depicts the “fishhook” or “S-shaped appearance” 
of the right ureter (white arrow) at the level of L3 vertebra 
with moderate hydronephrosis and dilatation of the ureter proximal 
to it and normal left kidney
Fig. 2 CT scan coronal images excretory phase showing moderate 
hydronephrosis present on the right side (blue arrow). The proximal 
portion of the right ureter is mildly dilated, passes behind the IVC 
at the level of the L3 vertebra causing fishhook-shaped deformity. No 
renal or ureteral stones are noted
Page 3 of 5
 Maro et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:573 
 
scarred tissue, ensured a good vascular supply, and 
brought together with tension free. The stenotic ret rocaval segment was removed. The proximal and dis tal end were spatulated about 7–10 mm at 180° apart, 
then stent was inserted. Corner sutures were placed 
to both ends by PDS 5–0. Watertight anastomosis was 
accomplished by completing the ureteral anastomosis 
utilizing the corner sutures in an interrupted manner.
A surgical drain was placed and removed on day 
fourth when there was insignificant drainage, and a 
Foley catheter left indwelling for 72 h.
After 6  weeks, control KUB ultrasonography 
revealed resolving right sided ureteropelvic hydro nephrosis, and the double-J stent was removed. Sixmonth patient follow-up demonstrated complete 
resolution of abdominal pain with no evidence of ure teral stricture.
Fig. 3 Computed tomography urography axial images; excretory 
phase on the right kidney at different levels showing the ureter (on 
the blue arrow) behind the IVC (white arrow) at the level of the L3 
vertebra
Fig. 4 A–B: showing retrocaval ureter crossing the inferior vena cava 
(white arrow) at the level of lumbar three (L3) vertebra (white arrow)

sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Retrocaval ureter is a vascular anomaly resulting in prox imal ureter crossing behind the inferior vena cava. It is 
an abnormality of the embryological development of the 
venous system and not of the urinary tract [6]. It is a rare 
congenital malformation with prevalence of 1:1500; its 
more common in male compared with female, with a 
ratio of 3:1(4). Most commonly, retrocaval ureter is found 
on the right side; however, it can rarely be found on the 
left side in patients with situs inversus and those with 
double vena cava [5].
This anomaly occurs between the 4th and 8th weeks of 
intrauterine development and is due to abnormal forma tion of infrarenal IVC from anteriorly located subcardi nal vein instead of supracardinal vein which are located 
posteriorly [5, 7]. In normal circumstances, the infrarenal 
IVC originates from dorsally located supracardinal vein, 
but when it develops from the ventrally located subcar dinal vein, the ureter is trapped posteriorly leading to 
pre-ureteral vena cava [2, 5]. This anomaly is three times 
more common in males than in females [3].
Bateson et  al. in 1969 classified retrocaval ureter into 
two types which are type 1 (low loop) of the proximal ure ter and type II (high loop) of the ureteropelvic junction. 
Type I retrocaval ureter is the most prevalent accounting 
for more than 90% of deformities and has extreme medial 
deviation of middle ureteric segment. The ureteric 
obstruction is typically at the edge of the iliopsoas mus cle, at which the ureter deviates cephalad before passing 
behind the vena cava. Normally, ureter crosses vena cava 
at the level of lumbar three vertebra (L3). This results in 
a proximal ureteral dilation and hydronephrosis which is 
seen in over 50% of patients, demonstrating a fishhook, 
reverse-J, or S-shaped ureteral curve [8].
Type II is a high loop of the ureteropelvic junction. It 
is less obstructive compared with type I. Its proximal 
ureter crosses inferior vena cava horizontally at the level 
of renal pelvis, forms a sickle deformity appearance and 
has lower medial deviation of the ureter with mild or no 
associated hydronephrosis and forms about 10% of all 
cases [8]. Most patients are asymptomatic, but those with 
symptoms present with flank pain and/or recurrent uri nary tract infections due to urinary stasis [9].
Imaging studies are important for an accurate preop erative diagnosis and successful surgical management. In 
our patient, abdominal ultrasound demonstrated hydro nephrosis and proximal hydroureter without calculus. 
In patients with retrocaval ureter, abdominopelvic CT 
IVU shows typical “fishhook” or “reverse J” or “S-shaped” 
deformity in the proximal dilated ureter with moderate 
hydronephrosis [10]. Nowadays, computed tomography 
intravenous urography (CT IVU) is preferred over IVU 
or retrograde pyelography (RPG), as it is less invansive 
Fig. 5 A and B: showing mobilization of the ureter from inferior 
vena cava and completed end to end uretero-ureteric anastomosis 
anterior to vena cava (white arrow)
Page 5 of 5
 Maro et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:573 
 
and may depict the anomaly in three dimensions, giv ing the most “wholesome” solution to the diagnosis [8]. 
The abdominal CT scan also makes it possible to make a 
differential diagnosis with primary idiopathic or second ary retroperitoneal fibrosis, and with any other cause of 
ureteral obstruction [3]. In a place where CT IVU cannot 
be done, retrograde pyelogram may be helpful; it dem onstrates spiral course of the ureter around inferior vena 
cava [ 9]. Our patient’s abdominopelvic CT scan showed 
moderate hydronephrosis with fishhook deformity of the 
right ureter and pelvi-ureteric junction obstruction.
Surgical management of retrocaval ureter is reserved 
for the symptomatic patient, patients with worsening 
hydronephrosis and deteriorating differential renal func tion [4]. Surgical management may be through retrop eritoneal or transperitoneal approach, it involves division 
of the ureter and repositioning it anterior to the inferior 
vena cava. This may be achieved through an anastomo sis between the renal pelvis and the ureter or a ureteroureteric anastomosis over a double-J stent. The segment 
behind the inferior vena cava, which may be aperistaltic, 
is either excised or left in situ [4].
The surgical approach can be open or laparoscopic, 
and in some cases robot-assisted where facilities permit 
[4]. Laparoscopic reconstructive techniques have been 
described by several authors who believe that it should be 
the technique of choice in the surgical treatment of the 
retrocaval ureter; this technique offers several advantages 
over conventional open surgery: it is minimally invasive, 
allows early ambulation with minimal complications such 
as postoperative wall pain or gastrointestinal ileus, and a 
shorter recovery period [11].
Conclusion
Retrocaval ureter can easily be misdiagnosed as neph rolithiasis. Retrocaval ureter can be asymptomatic or 
associated with non-specific symptoms, dominated by 
low back pain and intermittent flank pain; the diagno sis is confirmed by the CT IVU. Clinicians need to have 
high index of suspicion of retrocaval ureter in patients 
presenting with dull intermittent right flank pain typi cally in their third or fourth decade. Surgical treatment 
of patients with symptoms commonly completely relieves 
symptoms. Following up with ultrasound is the most 
important part in the management.
Acknowledgements
We would like to thank the whole surgical team for supporting our patient’s 
recovery.
Disclosure
This report has been published as per the CARE criteria.
Author contributions
CN and SN provided conceptual study development, searched the literature 
review, patient care and follow up, and writing the first manuscript draft. JL provided initial manuscript corrections. SBN provided radiological image 
interpretations. IM and KN were the chief surgeons, supervisors, and carried 
out final manuscript write-up. ON and CM critically reviewed the initial manuscript, provided correction,s and approved the final version of manuscript.
Funding
There was no funding concerning this article.
Availability of data and materials
This does not apply to this article because it is a case report.
Declarations
Ethics approval and consent to participate
This case report study was exempt from ethical approval at our institution, as 
this paper reports a single case that emerged during normal surgical practice.
Consent for publication
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of 
this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the written consent 
is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal.
Competing interests
The authors declare that they have no competing interests.
